Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A neighboring family has been affected by a house fire and requires immediate assistance with food and clothing.
Story: The headset pressed against my ear as I watched the seconds tick by on my screen, each one monitored by the compliance system. As a telemarketer, I was expected to take my breaks only at scheduled times, and any unscheduled absence could mean a warning or worse. My supervisor’s reminders echoed in my mind: “Every minute counts.” Yet, as a nun, my heart ached for the family next door whose home had just burned down. The convent phone rang with Sister Agnes’s voice, urgent and pleading, “We need you to help gather food and clothing for the family—right now.” I could almost see their faces, frightened and lost, waiting for comfort. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between the rigid demands of my job and the call to serve those in desperate need. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each expectation pulling me in opposite directions, and I felt the tension coil in my chest as I tried to decide what to do next.
